reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Every young adult should read this
reviews.reviewText: What are the pernicious effects of rape to the human psyche and to the human soul? After being raped by someone she thought was a friend, Eden’s identity completely disintegrates. She is no longer the way she used to be. She can never be that dorky clarinet playing girl again. The rape stole her innocence. This is a gripping story of a young girl’s plunge into the depths of darkness and despair then the eventual rising out of the ashes like the Phoenix. The rape evaporates her sense of worth and Eden engages in risky sexual behavior-sleeping with anyone and everyone without regards to the consequences . The rape makes her hostile to her friends and family. Her anger erupts consistently. She self sabotages her first true love. And she bottles up all her trauma never revealing the haunting events to anyone. Eden’s silence on the rape mirrors what happens to thousands of rape victims. Eden doesn’t report the sexual assault because of fear of reprisal, the overwhelming shame and the possibility that people might not believe her. This is very common with sexual assault victims. Eden’s story speaks true to many sexual assault victims’ stories. The imperative need to report sexual assault is something parents typically don’t talk about to their kids. Mist parents are too afraid to talk about the birds and the bees to their kids. So if parents aren’t going to warn their kids then I think every young adult could benefit by reading this cautionary tale.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This one had me all torn up! Edy was such a sweet girl who lost so much and thiugh her strength at the end shines tremendously, it is difficult to not feel sadness for her and all the dark trauma she experienced.And Joshua Miller.... a heartthrob of a character, doesn't get any more perfect then him

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars The perspective of unlikable victims is so important to the me too narrative
reviews.reviewText: Eden wasn’t a perfect victim. And because of this, her story gives a voice to so many women still blaming themselves. So many women who look back and wonder if the noise of society saying, well what were you wearing, why didn’t you tell anyone, holds any merit?It gives victims permission to share their stories. Even though it was years ago, even though you had a crush on him before the incident, even though he’s well liked by your community, even though you’ve developed undesirable coping mechanisms.I saw Eden as a child crying out desperately for help, and even her most trusted person couldn’t see it and treated her poorly first.I will say, there are some tropes and that’s why this wasn’t five stars for me, but I felt that the love interest was written in appropriately and realistically for someone who’s experienced trauma. It would’ve bothered me a lot if they lived happily ever after. But that’s the thing about trauma; it’s invasive. It stops you in your tracks when you’re trying to live out your life. It shows it’s ugly head when you’re trying to experience the beauties of life like falling in love.People who criticize victims like Eden are part of the problem and miss the point completely. My heart hurt for those that Eden was hurting, I think this brings up an important space to talk about how there needs to be room for survivors to get help and have their voices heard even if you go to the police you often will not get justice. Because when they’re made to make themselves small and hold it in to make everyone comfortable, the consequences are disastrous on an entire community.This book was an important one. I had a hard time getting immersed at first but a few chapters in and I couldn’t put it down. I’m glad I read this.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book is about sa so definitely a trigger warning. That being said it was so well written that I finished it in a day and a half. The main character is truly shown with all the good and bad and how something traumatic can change your life forever.

reviews.reviewerName: Write a review Write a review
reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2024
reviews.reviewText: recently found this book and it served as the perfect reentry into reading. Its captivating plot made me look forward to diving back into it after school. The storyline felt so realistic, showcasing a scenario that resonates with real-life experiences. Highly entertaining and a great motivator. Can’t wait to read the next book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I gave this books three stars. Not because I didn’t like the book, just the fact at times I felt like it was repetitive. Honestly Eden may not have been able to tell someone what happened to her, but I feel like someone would have noticed something was off and confronted her. Not any of the teen drama.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Read this book in three days! Loved it! It may be hard for some to read, it is very descriptive about the event that took place so just read the bio before you read. (Don't want to give any details away!)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This story was something different than everything I have read before. It really shows how you don't know what others go through and you need to show compassion. Eden's story is one of loss and lonelyness and a broken individual after trama. It is her story of overcoming. Though it may take time you have to be patient and ever supporting.

I started to read this book on a whim and could not put it down. From the time 5 minutes of violence shake up her life, we follow Eden down a rabbit hole of denial and self blame. It is all too real. An amazing and compelling read about how one event can impact your life and how you can come back from it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 19, 2024

reviews.reviewText: This book is about a girl call Eden. She was raped by her brother's bestfriend Kevin. So basically this revolves around her trauma and experience which is described in four different parts i.e freshmen year, sophomore year, junior year and senior year. (Please read trigger warning before reading this cause it is hard to read)

reviews.reviewTitle: Everyone needs to read this book
reviews.reviewText: What a perfect depiction of what it’s like to live after sexual trauma and how it’s like to be a survivor. I’m destroyed but I felt soooooo understood and heard.
